sources.title: YouTube's AI-powered dubbing is now available to many more creators
sources.snippet: YouTube has expanded its AI-powered auto-dubbing feature to hundreds of thousands of channels in its Partner Program, primarily those focusing on knowledge and informational content. This feature, first tested in mid-2023, automatically generates dubbed versions of videos in multiple languages at upload: if a video is originally in English, it can be dubbed into French, German, Hindi, Italian, Spanish, Indonesian, Japanese, and Portuguese; for videos starting in one of those languages, only English dubs are produced. Creators can preview these dubs before publishing and have the option to unpublish or delete them. While current dubs may sound unnatural, YouTube aims to improve tone, emotion, and ambiance in future updates. The company acknowledges potential imperfections in the translations and voice representation but is actively working on enhancing accuracy. Expansion to other content types is expected soon.

citation_mappings.claim_text: Built-in platform options (depends on eligibility): YouTube‚Äôs AI auto-dubbing/translation ‚Äì automatically generates translated audio for some creators (partner program). theverge.com
Meta AI for Reels ‚Äì auto translation/dubbing for short videos on Instagram/Facebook for eligible accounts. techradar.com

sources.title: VLC player demos real-time AI subtitling for videos
sources.snippet: At CES 2025, the open-source VLC media player showcased a new AI-powered feature that enables real-time subtitling and translation of videos directly on users' devices. Presented by VideoLAN President Jean-Baptiste Kempf, the demo highlighted the use of open-source AI models to generate and translate subtitles into over 100 languages completely offline, ensuring privacy and eliminating the need for cloud services. This feature is built directly into the VLC app, distinguishing it from earlier plug-ins that relied on platforms like OpenAI's Whisper. While the full rollout date hasn't been disclosed, the advancement demonstrates a significant leap in local AI integration for media playback. Additionally, VideoLAN announced that VLC has surpassed 6 billion downloads and continues to grow in active users despite the rise of streaming services.

citation_mappings.claim_text: Quick tips: If you only need subtitles, tools like WayinVideo, Zeemo, or ScreenApp are easiest. If you want dubbed audio with lip sync, Murf, BlipCut, and some dedicated AI translators handle that. For full local/offline without cloud, look for upcoming AI subtitling in players like VLC (still rolling out). theverge.com
